Hall | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1901|3|18|}} | birth_place = [[Peterborough, Ontario]], Canada | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1990|8|29|1901|3|18}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], US | occupation = Philosopher, writer | citizenship = United States | ethnicity = | period = 1919–1990 | subject = [[Philosophy]] | alma_mater = | influences = | influenced = | notableworks = ''[[The Secret Teachings of All Ages]]''
''The Lost Keys Of Freemasonry'' | signature= }} '''Manly Palmer Hall''' (March 18, 1901 – August 29, 1990) was a [[Canadian]]-born [[author]], lecturer, astrologer and [[mysticism|mystic]]. He is best known for his 1928 work ''The Secret Teachings of All Ages''. Over his 70 year career, he gave thousands of lectures, including two at Carnegie Hall, and published over 150 volumes. In 1934, he founded The [[Philosophical Research Society]] in Los Angeles, which he dedicated to the "Truth Seekers of All Time", with a research library, lecture hall and publishing house. Many of his lectures can be found online and his books are still in print. ==Early life== Manly P. Hall was born in 1901{{Cite web|url=http://gnosticwarrior.com/manly-p-hall|title=Manly P Hall {{!}} GnosticWarrior.com|website=gnosticwarrior.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-15}} in [[Peterborough, Ontario]], Canada,{{Cite web|url=http://www.newdawnmagazine.com/articles/secret-teachings-reborn-the-mysterious-life-of-manly-p-hall|title=Secret Teachings Reborn: The Mysterious Life of Manly P. Hall {{!}} New Dawn : The World's Most Unusual Magazine|last=Magazine|first=New Dawn|website=www.newdawnmagazine.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-15}} to William S. Hall, a dentist, and Louise Palmer Hall, a [[chiropractor]] and member of the [[Rosicrucian Fellowship]].{{Cite web|url=http://new.prs.org/about-prs/|title=About {{!}} Philosophical Research Society|website=new.prs.org|language=en-CA|access-date=2017-06-15}} In 1919 Hall, who never knew his father, moved from [[Canada]] to [[Los Angeles, California]], with his maternal grandmother to reunite with his birth mother, who was living in Santa Monica, and was almost immediately drawn to the arcane world of mysticism, esoteric philosophies, and their underlying principles. Hall delved deeply into "teachings of lost and hidden traditions, the golden verses of Hindu gods, Greek philosophers and Christian mystics, and the spiritual treasures waiting to be found within one's own soul." Less than a year later, Hall booked his first lecture, and the topic was [[reincarnation]].{{cite book |last=Sahagun |first=Louis |title=Master of the Mysteries: The Life of Manly Palmer Hall |place=Port Townsend, Washington |publisher=Process Media |year=2008 }}{{rp|15–18}} He soon took over as preacher of the Church of the People in 1919, at Trinity Auditorium in downtown Los Angeles. Hall was ordained a minister in the Church of the People on May 17, 1923, and "a few days later, he was elected permanent pastor of the church."{{rp|28}} His first publications consisted of two small pamphlets, "The Breastplate of the High Priest" (1920), and "Wands and Serpents." Between 1921 and 1923 he wrote three books, ''The Initiates of the Flame'' published in October 1922, ''The Ways of the Lonely Ones'' published in 1922, and ''The Lost Keys of Freemasonry'' published in March 1923. Hall did not become a Freemason until 1954, more than thirty years after this book was published.http://freemasonry.bcy.ca/biography/esoterica/hall_m_p/hall_m_p.html During the early 1920s, Carolyn Lloyd and her daughter Estelle—members of a family that controlled a valuable oil field in [[Ventura County, California]]—began "sending a sizeable portion of their oil income to Hall," who used the money to travel and acquire a substantial personal library of ancient literature.{{rp|38–43}} Hall's "first trip around the world to study the lives, customs and religions of countries in Asia and Europe," which commenced December 5, 1923, was paid for by donations from Carolyn Lloyd and her congregation.{{rp|41}} Later in 1928, at the age of 27 years, he published ''An Encyclopedic Outline of Masonic, Hermetic, Qabbalistic and Rosicrucian Symbolical Philosophy: Being an Interpretation of the Secret Teachings concealed within the Rituals, Allegories and Mysteries of all Ages'', which is more commonly referred to as ''The Secret Teachings of All Ages''.{{cite book |last=Hall |first=Manly P. |title=An Encyclopedic Outline of Masonic, Hermetic, Qabbalistic and Rosicrucian Symbolical Philosophy: Being an Interpretation of the Secret Teachings concealed within the Rituals, Allegories and Mysteries of all Ages |edition=Diamond Jubilee |place=Los Angeles, California |publisher=The [[Philosophical Research Society]], Inc. |year=1988 |orig-year=1928; facsimile, with new prefaces |isbn=0-89314-830-X |postscript=  reduced paperback. Also 0-89314-546-7, 0-89314-548-3 reduced casebound, 0-89314-830-X reduced paperback; }}{{rp|vi}} The major books which followed include ''The Dionysian Artificers'' (1936), ''Freemasonry of the Ancient Egyptians'' (1937), and ''Masonic Orders of Fraternity'' (1950). ==''The Secret Teachings of All Ages''== Hall became sufficiently known and respected as a lecturer and interpreter of the writings of the ancients, and the most useful and practical elements of classical idealism, that he successfully appealed, through advertisements and word of mouth, for funds to finance the book that became ''The Secret Teachings of All Ages - An Encyclopedia Outline of Masonic, Hermetic, Qabbalistic and Rosicrucian Symbolic Philosophy'', whose original cost of publication in 1928 was estimated to be $150,000,{{rp|20–21, 50}} although the price of individual copies varied. According to original subscription agreements on file at the Philosophical Research Society, editions were sold by subscription for $75 on a pre-publication basis, but "the price of this edition after delivery by the printer is understood to be One Hundred Dollars." Under the subscription terms, $15 was due at signing of the agreement, and "the balance of Sixty Dollars in four equal monthly payments each."Several original subscription documents were located by Edie Shapiro, PRS Librarian, on August 6, 2012. Ms. Shapiro stated: "It appears the price was $50, $75 or $100 (or complimentary, depending)," so an exact accounting of the costs may not be possible to reconstruct. The H.S. Crocker Company of San Francisco agreed to publish the book "if Hall could secure the interest of book designer John Henry Nash, who once worked as a printer to the Vatican."{{rp|52}} After ''The Secret Teachings of All Ages'' was published, Hall "went from being just another earnest young preacher in the City of Angels to becoming an icon of the increasingly influential metaphysical movement sweeping the country in the 1920s. His book challenged assumptions about society's spiritual roots and made people look at them in new ways."{{rp|52}} Hall dedicated ''The Secret Teachings of All Ages'' to "the proposition that concealed within the emblematic figures, allegories and rituals of the ancients is a secret doctrine concerning the inner mysteries of life, which doctrine has been preserved ''in toto'' among a small band of initiated minds."{{cite book |last=Hall |first=Manly P. |title=An Encyclopedic Outline of Masonic, Hermetic, Qabbalistic and Rosicrucian Symbolical Philosophy: Being an Interpretation of the Secret Teachings concealed within the Rituals, Allegories and Mysteries of all Ages |edition=Subscribers' |year=1928 |place=San Francisco, California |publisher=H. S. Crocker & Co. |url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/eso/sta/ }}{{rp|20}} As one writer put it: "The result was a gorgeous, dreamlike book of mysterious symbols, concise essays and colorful renderings of mythical beasts rising out of the sea, and angelic beings with lions' heads presiding over somber initiation rites in torch-lit temples of ancestral civilizations that had mastered latent powers beyond the reach of modern man."{{rp|50}} In 1988, Hall himself wrote: "The greatest knowledge of all time should be available to the twentieth century not only in the one shilling editions of the Bohn Library in small type and shabby binding, but in a book that would be a monument, not merely a coffin. John Henry Nash agreed with me."{{cite book |last=Hall |first=Manly P. |title=The Secret Teachings of All Ages: Reader's Edition |edition=Reader's |place=New York |publisher=Jeremy P. Tarcher/Penguin |year=2003 |postscript=. The Reader's Edition is a trade paperback (6" wide and 9" tall). |isbn=1-58542-250-9 }}{{rp|4}} ==Personal life== Hall and his followers went to extreme lengths to keep any gossip or information that could tarnish his image from being publicized, and little is known about his first marriage, on April 28, 1930, to Fay B. deRavenne, then 28, who had been his secretary during the preceding five years. The marriage was not a happy one; his friends never discussed it, and Hall removed virtually all information about her from his papers following her suicide on February 22, 1941.{{rp|55, 97}} Following a long friendship, on December 5, 1950, Hall married Marie Schweikert Bauer (following her divorce from George Bauer), and the marriage though stormy was happier than his first.{{cite web|last=Nichols |first=Kimberly |url=http://newtopiamagazine.wordpress.com/2012/12/15/the-maestro-and-the-boy-the-kindness-of-manly-p-hall/ |title=The Maestro and the Boy: The Kindness of Manly P. Hall | Newtopia Magazine |publisher=Newtopiamagazine.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-06}} Marie Schweikert Bauer Hall died April 21, 2005.{{rp|120, 127, 133, 278}} She was born on June 24, 1904. ===Career as philosopher=== During the early 1930s, using money from the Lloyds, "Hall traveled to France and England, where he acquired his most extensive collection of rare books and manuscripts in alchemy and esoteric fields from London auctioneer, Sotheby & Company." Through an agent, due to the depressed economic conditions of the era, Hall was able to buy a substantial number of rare books and manuscripts at reasonable prices. When Caroline Lloyd died in 1946, she bequeathed Hall a home, $15,000 in cash, and "a roughly $10,000 portion of her estate's annual income from shares in the world's largest oil companies for 38 years."{{rp|60}} In 1934, Hall founded the [[Philosophical Research Society]] (PRS) in Los Angeles, California, a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization[http://prs.org/wpcms/?page_id=157 The Philosophical Research Society's Tax Exempt Status] – The Philosophical Research Society's declaration of its 501(c)3 nonprofit status on its website, retrieved December 12, 2010. dedicated to the study of religion, mythology, metaphysics, and the occult.{{cite web|url=http://www.prs.org/about.htm |title=About the Philosophical Research Society |accessdate=2008-08-07 |publisher=Philosophical Research Society |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ZtkINocD?url=http://www.prs.org/about.htm |archivedate=2008-08-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He was a Knight Patron of the Masonic Research Group of San Francisco, with which he was associated for a number of years prior to his Masonic affiliations. On June 28, 1954, Hall initiated as a [[Freemason]] into Jewel Lodge No. 374, San Francisco (now the United Lodge); passed September 20, 1954; and raised November 22, 1954. He took the Scottish Rite Degrees a year later.[http://www.manlyphall.org/ The Manly Palmer Hall Archive], retrieved September 28, 2009. He later received his 32° in the Valley of San Francisco AASR (SJ).{{cite book| last = Denslow| first =William R.| authorlink = | title = 10,000 Famous Freemasons, vol. ii | publisher = [Trenton, MO. : Missouri Lodge of Research / Educational Bureau, Royal Arch Mason Magazine]| year = 1958| page = 165}} On December 8, 1973 (47 years after writing ''The Secret Teachings of All Ages''), Hall was recognized as a 33° [[Freemasonry|Mason]] (the highest honor conferred by the Supreme Council of the [[Scottish Rite]]) at a ceremony held at the [[Philosophical Research Society]] (PRS)[http://prs.org/mphbio.htm MPH Biography]Manly P. Hall's Obituary, Scottish Rite Journal, November, 1990, p. 22. {{cite web |url=http://www.srmason-sj.org/what/educ/srj.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070313160504/http://www.srmason-sj.org/what/educ/srj.html |archivedate=2007-03-13 |df= }}. (Note: archives don't go back this far so this reference is in question. However, the [http://prs.org/mphbio.htm Philosophical Research Society Manly Palmer Hall biography] states this (word-for-word) except the text on this page stated the 33° is the highest degree conferred by the Scottish Rite, a rare and high honor, Manly Palmer Hall, was given the highest honor conferred by the Scottish Rite in recognition of his esteemed work: The Grand Cross of Scottish Rite Freemasonry, Southern Jurisdiction, Washington, D.C. in 1985 (can only be conferred on 33rd Degree Masons). [http://www.scottishrite.org/web/SRpublications/deHoyos-chapter3.htm The Supreme Council – Is It True What They Say About Freemasonry? – The Methods of Anti-Masons] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928031920/http://www.scottishrite.org/web/SRpublications/deHoyos-chapter3.htm |date=2007-09-28 }} questions Hall's Mason authority status.). [[File:MPH-Carnegie-Hall-ticket-1942.jpg|thumb|Ticket for Manly P. Hall at Carnegie Hall, Dec. 2, 1942]] In his over 70-year career, Hall delivered approximately 8,000 lectures in the [[United States]] and abroad, authored over 150 books and essays, and wrote countless [[magazine]] articles. He appears in the introduction to the 1938 film ''[[When Were You Born]]'', a murder mystery that uses astrology as a key plot point. Hall wrote the original story for the film (screenplay by Anthony Coldeway) and is also credited as the narrator. In 1942, Manly Hall spoke to an attendance-setting audience at [[Carnegie Hall]], on "The Secret Destiny of America," which later became a book of the same title. He returned in 1945 for another well-attended lecture at the famous venue, titled: "Plato's Prophecy of Worldwide Democracy." {{cite web|url=http://www.carnegiehall.org/PerformanceHistorySearch/#!search=manly%20p.%20hall |title=Carnegie Hall : Performance History Search |publisher=Carnegiehall.org |accessdate=2015-05-06}} ==Legacy== The PRS still maintains a research library of over 50,000 volumes,{{cite web|url=http://www.usc.edu/libraries/archives/arc/lasubject/records/id93.html |title=About the Philosophical Research Society |accessdate=2008-08-07 |work=University of Southern California Archival Research Center: LA as Subject Database |publisher=University of Southern California |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ZtkQErVd?url=http://www.usc.edu/libraries/archives/arc/lasubject/records/id93.html |archivedate=2008-08-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and also sells and publishes metaphysical and spiritual books, mostly those authored by Hall.{{cite web|url=http://www.macraesbluebook.com/search/company.cfm?company=589021 |title=About the Philosophical Research Society |accessdate=2008-08-07 |work=McRae’s Bluebook |publisher=McRae’s Bluebook |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ZtkUkewg?url=http://www.macraesbluebook.com/search/company.cfm?company=589021 |archivedate=2008-08-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} After his death, some of Manly Hall's rare alchemy books were sold to keep the PRS in operation. "Acquisition of the Manly Palmer Hall Collection in 1995 provided the Getty Research Institute with one of the world's leading collections of alchemy, esoterica, and hermetica."{{cite web |url=http://www.getty.edu/research/special_collections/highlights/alchemy/index.html |title=Alchemy—Special Collections |work=The Getty Research Institute |publisher=J. Paul Getty Trust |accessdate=6 January 2015 }} It was reported in 2010 that President Ronald Reagan adopted some ideas and phrasing from Hall’s book ''The Secret Destiny of America'' (1944), using them in speeches and essays.[http://voices.washingtonpost.com/political-bookworm/2010/04/reagan_and_the_occult.html "Reagan and the Occult" by Mitch Horowitz, ''The Washington Post'', Political Bookworm, April 30th, 2010] ==Other works== *(1988) ''Meditation Symbols In Eastern & Western Mysticism-Mysteries of the Mandala'' {{cite book |last=Hall |first=Manly P. |title=Meditation symbols in Eastern & Western mysticism : mysteries of the mandala |place=Los Angeles, California |publisher=[[Philosophical Research Society]] |year=1988 |isbn=0-89314-543-2 }} *(1923) ''The Lost Keys Of Freemasonry'' {{cite book |title=The Lost Keys of Masonry or The Legend of Hiram Abiff |first=Manly P. |last=Hall |edition=Special students |place=Santa Monica, California |publisher=Priv. pub. by the author |year=1923 |url=https://archive.org/details/The.Lost.Keys.Of.Masonry.Manly.P.Hall.1923 }} *(1922) ''The Initiates of the Flame''. The first published book by Hall{{cite book |title=The Initiates of the Flame |place=Los Angeles |publisher=The Phoenix Press |year=1934 |orig-year=1922; reprinted, with illustrations by J. Augustus Knapp |url=https://archive.org/details/initiatesofflame00hall }} *''Lectures in Ancient Philosophy: An Introduction to Practical Ideals'' *The Adepts Series *''Lady of Dreams: A fable in the manner of the Chinese'' (Los Angeles, 1943) *(1980) The Blessed Angels: A [[Monograph]] {{cite book |last=Hall |first=Manly P. |title=The blessed Angels: The Reality of Things Unseen |place=Los Angeles, California |publisher=[[Philosophical Research Society]] |year=1980 |isbn=0893148075 }} **(1929) ''Lectures on Ancient Philosophy—An Introduction to the Study and Application of Rational Procedure'' {{cite book |title=Lectures on Ancient Philosophy—An Introduction to the Study and Application of Rational Procedure |publisher=The Hall Publishing Company |place=Los Angeles, California |year=1929 |chapter=19 Rosicrucian and Masonic Origins |chapter-url=http://the_mystic_light.tripod.com/rosicrucian_and_masonic.htm }} *(1933) Introduction to [[Max Heindel]]'s ''[[Blavatsky]] and The Secret Doctrine'', 1933 {{cite book |last=Heindel |first=Max |title=Blavatsky and the Secret Doctrine, by Max Heindel; with a short biography of the author; introduction by Manly Hall |place=Los Angeles, California |publisher=Phoenix Press |year=1933 |chapter=Introduction |chapter-url=http://rosicrucianzine.tripod.com/introductionhpb.htm }} *(1944) ''The Secret Destiny of America'' {{cite book |last=Hall |first=Manly P. |title=The Secret Destiny of America |place=Los Angeles, California |publisher=Philosophical Research Society |year=1944 }} *(1951) ''America's Assignment with Destiny'' {{cite book |last=Hall |first=Manly P. |title=America's Assignment with Destiny |place=Los Angeles, California |publisher=[[Philosophical Research Society]] |orig-year=1951 |year=1994 |isbn=0893145025 }} *Unofficial Listing of All Books by Manly P. Hall, with topics {{cite web |url=http://www.manlyphall.info//mph-book-list.htm |title=Manly P. Hall's Books with Topic Listings |editor=Alan Harris |accessdate=6 January 2015 }} *Complete PDF archive of Manly P. Hall's Journals: ''The All-Seeing Eye'', ''Horizon'', and ''PRS Journal'' {{cite web|url=http://www.manlyphall.info/journals-index.htm |title=Complete Archive of Manly P. Hall's Journals |publisher=Manlyphall.info |date= |accessdate=2018-07-01}} *Manly P. Hall: Resources and Inspirations {{cite web|url=http://www.manlyphall.info/index.htm |title=Manly P. Hall: Resources and Inspirations |publisher=Alan Harris |date=|accessdate=2018-07-01}} *A Monthly Letter Devoted to Spiritual and Philosophical Problems {{cite web |url=http://www.manlyphall.info/a-monthly-letter |title=A Monthly Letter Devoted to Spiritual and Philosophical Problems |first=Manly P. |last=Hall |publisher=The Phoenix Press |place=Los Angeles |postscript=. 1934-8, 1944-5. }} **''[[Atlantis]], An Interpretation'' **''Symbolic Essays'' **''[[Noah]] and His Wonderful Ark'' ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book | last = Sahagun | first = Louis | title = Master of the Mysteries: The Life of Manly Palmer Hall | publisher = Process | year = 2008 | location = | isbn = 1-934170-02-X }} *{{cite book | last = Horowitz | first = Mitch | title = Occult America: The Secret History of How Mysticism Shaped Our Nation | publisher = Bantam | year = 2009 | location = New York | isbn = 978-0-553-38515-1 }} *Pontiac, Ronnie (2012) [http://newtopiamagazine.wordpress.com/2012/12/15/the-maestro-and-the-boy-the-kindness-of-manly-p-hall/ "The Maestro and the Boy: The Kindness of Manly P. Hall"] *{{wikiquote-inline}} *{{wikisource-inline}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hall, Manly Palmer}} [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:American Freemasons]] [[Category:American occult writers]] [[Category:American Theosophists]] [[Category:Canadian academics]] [[Category:Canadian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Canadian philosophers]] [[Category:Canadian Theosophists]] [[Category:Esotericists]] [[Category:Hermeticism]] [[Category:Mystics]] [[Category:People from Peterborough, Ontario]] [[Category:Philosophers from California]] [[Category:Writers from Los Angeles]] [[Category:Writers from Ontario]] [[Category:Tarotologists]]

[[DJ Science College]] | occupation =Politician | profession =Philosopher | cabinet =[[:Template:Government of Prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto|Government of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | blank1 =Award(s) | data1 =[[Habib Jalib|Habib Jalib Award]] | website = | nickname = | allegiance = | branch = | serviceyears = | rank = | unit = | commands = | battles = | awards = | military_blank1 = | military_data1 = | imagesize = | term_start = 1998 | term_end = 2003 | term_start1 =1977 | term_end1 =Unknown | term_start2 =20 December 1971 | term_end2 = 13 August 1973 | order3 =Vice-President of the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] | office3 = | term_start3 =30 November 1967 | term_end3 =22 October 1974 | predecessor3 = Office Established | successor3 =Dr. [[Mubashir Hassan]] | order4 = Founding Member of the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] | office4 = | term_start4 =30 November 1967 | term_end4 =1977 | order5 =President of [[National Students Federation]] | office5 = | term_start5 =4 July 1963 | term_end5 =30 November 1967 | predecessor5 =Johar Hassan | successor5 =Rasheed Hassan Khan | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | birthname = | blank2 = | data2 = | blank3 = | data3 = | blank4 = | data4 = | blank5 = | data5 = | military_blank2 = | military_data2 = | military_blank3 = | military_data3 = | military_blank4 = | military_data4 = | military_blank5 = | military_data5 = }} '''Meraj Muhammad Khan Afridi''' ({{lang-ur|'''معراج محمد خان'''}}; 20 October 1938 – 21 July 2016),{{cite news |title=Time running out to stem crises |url=http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Regional/Karachi/21-Oct-2008/Time-running-out-to-stem-crises |work=[[The Nation (Pakistan)]] |date=21 October 2008 |accessdate=5 March 2011 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} was a Pakistani [[Socialism in Pakistan|socialist]] politician and philosopher. He played a key role in founding of Pakistan's 2 major (except ML) and 1 minor political parties. He was noted as one of the key philosopher and founding personality of the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) and as a major contributor to the initial Left of Centre/Social Democratic so-called the Basic Programme of the [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] (PTI). He was also founder of Qaumi Mahaz-i-Azadi which he founded after leaving PPP in 1977. In addition, he is well known and influential socialist figure in the country, and known for his political struggle and advocacy against [[anti-capitalist convergence]] and the support of the [[social democracy]].{{cite book|last=Jones|first=edited by Mike O'Donnell, Bryn|title=Resurgence of the Sixties: Radicalism Revisited|year=2010|publisher=Anthem|location=London|isbn=978-1-84331-895-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3LGy0yWmEVMC&pg=PA77&lpg=PA77&dq=meraj+muhammad+khan+PPP&source=bl&ots=CATzQ5p-jZ&sig=CE8Hi7s4qMQAbFz1mfyBlZBAji4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QYp1UpuPM-TAigK3tYC4Ag&ved=0CF8Q6AEwDA#v=onepage&q=meraj%20muhammad%20khan%20PPP&f=true}} ==Biography== Meraj Muhammad Khan was born on 20 October 1938 in [[Farrukhabad]], Uttar Pradesh, [[British Indian Empire]] to an educated Pukhto speaking family of Zakha Khel [[Afridi]] tribe of [[Pashtuns|Pashtun]] origin.{{cite news|last=Naimat Khan|title='His Excellency' Meraj Muhammad Khan|url=http://www.thefrontierpost.com/article/23564/|accessdate=3 November 2013|newspaper=Frontier Post|date=30 June 2013}} He was the youngest of four sons and his father, Hakeem Molvi Taj Muhammad Khan, was a [[Homoeopathy|homoeopath]] who practised the methods of [[Unani|Greek medicine]] in [[Quetta]], [[Balochistan Province|Balochistan]]. His elder brother was the famous renown Pakistani journalist [[Minhaj Barna]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.newspakistan.pk/2011/11/04/A-tribute-to-My-grandfather-Minhaj-Barna/|title=A tribute to: My grandfather – Minhaj Barna|last=Khan|first=Momina|date=2011-11-04|website=News Pakistan|access-date=2017-02-13}} After graduating from local high school in 1956, Khan moved to [[Karachi]] where he attended [[DJ Science College]] and later pursued his higher education at [[Karachi University]] in 1957. He earned a BA in philosophy and [[humanities]] in 1960, and an MA in philosophy in 1962. ===Communism and PPP activism=== He came to public prominence in 1960s while studying at Karachi University. During this time, there was a debating competition in which students from all the colleges of Karachi were participating.{{cite news|last=Khan|first=Lal|title=Pakistan's Other Story: 6. Witness to Revolution – Veterans of the 1968–69 upheaval|url=http://www.marxist.com/pakistans-other-story-6.htm|accessdate=3 November 2013|newspaper=Marxist News, Pakistan|date=22 May 2009 }} At this competition, some activists of the [[Communist Party of Pakistan|Communist Party]] were sitting in the audience, who asked him to join the Communist Party. He became an active member of the [[National Students Federation]], eventually becoming NSF's president in 1963. Khan turned the NSF into a militant student political organisation that campaigned for the rights of students. In 1967, he left the NSF after secretly learning of a socialist convention being held in [[Lahore]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]]. He was among those who founded the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] (PPP) and fully endorsed [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] for the PPP's chairmanship. Through the PPP, he went into mainstream politics and successfully contested in the [[Pakistani general elections, 1970|1970 general elections]] on a PPP platform from the [[Karachi]] constituency. ===Labour ministry (1971–1973)=== In December 1971, Khan was appointed [[Ministry of Manpower (Pakistan)|Minister for Manpower]] and directed the [[Ministry of Labour (Pakistan)|Ministry of Labour]] (MoL) in Prime Minister [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]]'s government. In 1972, his tenure saw a [[Karachi labour unrest of 1972|major labour strike]] in Karachi; though it was peacefully resolved by Meraj's intervention. It was later reported in [[Pakistani newspapers|newspapers]] and television that the labour strike was actually a competition between two PPP ministers, Meraj and [[Law Minister of Pakistan|Law Minister]] [[Abdul Hafiz Pirzada]] for the control of the labour. Meraj's radical leftist group was in direct competition against Law Minister Pirzada's [[Chinese Communist Party|Pro-Peking]] group. However, Meraj's denied all accusations on the television.{{cite book|last=Khan|first=Naveeda|title=Beyond Crisis: Re-evaluating Pakistan|year=2012|publisher=Routledge|location=Abingdon [u.k]|isbn=1136517588|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lydM6gRQH6EC&pg=PT321&dq=meraj+muhammad+khan+East+Pakistan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Wxd2UoDpNuiuiAL19IBY&ved=0CEUQuwUwAg#v=onepage&q=meraj%20muhammad%20khan%20East%20Pakistan&f=true}} In 1973, Mairaj fell out with the Bhutto government when Bhutto started to compromise on his so-called [[Socialism in Pakistan|Socialist agenda]] and the regime resorted to repressive measures. As time passee, his differences with Prime Minister Bhutto grew and he left the PPP to reorganise the [[National Students Federation|NSF]]. However, Miraj fell into political isolation, never to regain his political credibility and popularity. Commenting on PPP, Meraj later revealed that "the radical (leftist) rhetoric was more than a mask designed to win and retain power."{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Tariq|title=The Duel: Pakistan on the Flight Path of American Power|year=2008|publisher=Scribner|location=New York [u.s.]|isbn=1471105881|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SELWCgBjYSwC&pg=RA1-PA1950&dq=meraj+mohamed+khan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_RZ2UtyDDcGligKV2oCQBA&ved=0CFUQuwUwBQ#v=onepage&q=meraj%20mohamed%20khan&f=true}} He once said: "[[Ali Bhutto]] was a great man ... but he could be cruel."{{cite web|last=Allam|first=Zalan|title=Understanding Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto,|url=http://sixhour.com/understanding%20zulfiqar%20ali%20bhutto.htm|publisher=Sixth hour|accessdate=3 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908032638/http://sixhour.com/understanding%20zulfiqar%20ali%20bhutto.htm|archivedate=8 September 2014|df=dmy-all}} ===Political activism (1980s-until his death)=== After leaving the PPP, he became a prominent democratic activist and leftist leader of the [[Movement for Restoration of Democracy]] (MRD) opposing the [[Zia regime|military government]] of [[President of Pakistan|President]] General [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|Zia-ul-Haq]].{{cite web|last=Pakistan Herald|title=Details of Meraj Muhammad Khan|url=http://www.pakistanherald.com/Profile/Meraj-Muhammad-Khan-792|work=Pakistan Herald|publisher=Pakistan Herald|accessdate=3 November 2013}} ===Awami Insaf and the birth of PTI Basic Programme=== In 1998, he joined the center-left/centrist [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] (PTI) headed by [[Imran Khan]], but resigned from the party in 2003, citing differences with Khan. He then joined the [[Mazdoor Kisan Party]], which later merged with the [[Communist Party of Pakistan]] to form the [[Communist Mazdoor Kissan Party]]. He died in Karachi on 21 July 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/136653-Senior-politician-Meraj-Muhammad-Khan-passes-away|title=Senior politician Meraj Muhammad Khan passes away|work=thenews.com.pk|accessdate=21 July 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} 11. http://www.newspakistan.pk/2011/11/04/A-tribute-to-My-grandfather-Minhaj-Barna/ {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khan, Meraj Muhammad}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:People from Farrukhabad]] [[Category:People from Quetta]] [[Category:University of Karachi alumni]] [[Category:Politicians from Karachi]] [[Category:Pakistani communists]] [[Category:Pakistani Marxists]] [[Category:Communist Party of Pakistan politicians]] [[Category:Pakistani philosophers]] [[Category:Pakistani academics]] [[Category:Pakistan Peoples Party politicians]] [[Category:Government of Benazir Bhutto staffers and personnel]] [[Category:Muhajir people]] [[Category:Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf politicians]]

A '''Morton's fork''' is a type of [[false dilemma]] in which contradictory observations lead to the same conclusion. It is said to have originated with the collecting of taxes by [[John Morton (bishop)|John Morton]].
The earliest known use of the term dates from the mid-19th century and the only known earlier mention is a claim by [[Francis Bacon]] of an extant tradition.<ref name="ODPF">{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1O214-MortonsFork.html |title=Morton's Fork |work=Oxford Dictionary of Phrase and Fable |publisher=Encyclopedia.com |access-date=12 September 2017}}</ref>
==Dilemma== Under [[Henry VII of England|Henry VII]] John Morton was made archbishop of Canterbury in 1486, then Lord Chancellor in 1487. He raised taxation funds for his king by holding that someone living modestly must be saving money and, therefore, could afford taxes, whereas someone living extravagantly obviously was rich and, therefore, could afford taxes.<ref name="OED">{{cite book | url=http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/Morton's-Fork | title=Morton's Fork | publisher=Oxford English Dictionary}}</ref><ref name="ODPF"/>
In some instances, such as Morton's original use of the fallacy, it may be that one of the two observations is probably valid, but the other is pure [[Sophism | sophistry]]: evidence of possessing wealth may be genuinely irrelevant to having a source of taxable income.
In other cases, it may be that neither observation may be relied upon to support the conclusion properly. For example, asserting that a person suspected of a crime who is acting nervously must have something to feel guilty about, while a person who acts calmly and confidently must be practised or skilled at hiding guilt. Either observation therefore has little, if any, [[relevance (law)|probative]] value, as each could equally be evidence for the opposite conclusion.
==Examples== "[[Morton's fork coup]]" is a maneuver in the game of [[Contract bridge|bridge]] that uses the principle of Morton's Fork.<ref>Frey et al. (1976). ''The Official Encyclopedia of Bridge'', p. 295. {{ISBN|0-517-52724-3}}.</ref><ref>Gray, Robert. [[The Bridge World]], March 1973</ref>
An episode of the television series ''[[Fargo (TV series)|Fargo]]'' is entitled "[[Morton's Fork (Fargo)|Morton's Fork]]", after the dilemma. It is also mentioned in NCIS Los Angeles season 5 episode 16, "Fish Out of Water."
==See also== * [[Sophie's Choice (novel)|''Sophie's Choice'']]

'''Myroslav Popovych''' ({{Lang-uk|Мирослав Володимирович Попович}}; 12 April 1930, [[Zhytomyr]] – 10 February 2018, [[Kyiv]]) was a Ukrainian philosopher, DA, professor, Academician of the [[National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine]].
==Biography== {{External media |align =right |width = 300 |image1 = [https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Y-nNUv8rBrE/maxresdefault.jpg №-1.] |image2 = [http://i.obozrevatel.ua/8/1242572/527012.jpg №-2.] |image3 = [http://image.tsn.ua/media/images2/original/Mar2012/383573801.jpg №-3.] |image4 = [http://argumentua.com/sites/default/files/imagecache/Full_tekst_600x/article/im578x383-4E24D542-6699-4F19-858.jpg №-4] }} Popovych was born on 12 April 1930 in [[Zhytomyr]], in the [[Ukrainian SSR]] of the [[Soviet Union]] (in present-day [[Ukraine]]). In 1953 he graduated from the [[National Taras Shevchenko University of Kiev|Taras Shevchenko University]] of [[Kiev]], philosophy department. From 2001 he is the director of the [[Hryhorii Skovoroda|Skovoroda]] Institute of Philosophy of the [[National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine]]. In 2003 he was elected Academician of the Ukrainian National Academy of Sciences.
==Publications==
* "On the Philosophical Analysis of the Science Language" ("О философском анализе языка науки") (1966) * "Logic and Scientific Cognition" ("Логіка і наукове пізнання" (1971) * "Philosophical Aspects of Semantics" ("Философские вопросы семантики" (1975) * "Outline of History of Logical Ideas in the Context of Culture and History" ("Очерк истории логических идей в культурно-историческом контексте") (1979) * "Hryhoriy [[Skovoroda]]" ("Григорій Сковорода") (1984, co-authorship) * "Outlook of Ancient Slavs" ("Мировозрение древних словян» (1985) * "[[Mykola Gogol]]" ("Микола Гоголь» (1989) * "Ukraine and Europe: the Rightists and the Leftists" ("Україна і Європа: праві і ліві") (1996) * "Rationality and Dimensions of Human Life" ("Раціональність і виміри людського буття» (1997) * "Outline of the History of Ukrainian Culture" ("Нарис історії культури України") (1999) * "Universal Encyclopedia" ("Універсальний словник-енциклопедія") (1999, chief editor) * "Red Century" ("Червоне століття") (2005) * "Being Human" ("Бути людиною") (2011)
== References == *[http://www.univ.kiev.ua/ua/news/1725/]
== External links == * [http://zhzh.info/news/2010-04-12-7139 Мирослав Попович отмечает 80-летие] (Myroslav Popovych is 80) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101127170559/http://nbuv.gov.ua/people/popovych.html Попович Мирослав Володимирович] (Popovych Myroslav Volodymyrovycn) * [http://zhzh.info/publ/8-1-0-2123 Попович М.В.] * [http://calendar.interesniy.kiev.ua/Event.aspx?id=2952 Попович М.В.] * [http://www.moral.gov.ua/pages.php?id=28 Попович М.В.] * [http://logos-ukraine.com.ua/project/index.php?project=piued3&id=1444 Попович М.В.] * [http://knpu.gov.ua/content/popovich-miroslav-volodimirovich Попович М.В.]

{{Infobox philosopher |region = |era = |color = lightsteelblue |image = |image_size = |caption = |name = Patricia Greenspan |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |school_tradition = |main_interests = [[moral philosophy]], [[moral psychology]], [[philosophy of action]], [[Deontic logic]], [[free will]], [[moral responsibility]], [[emotion]], [[ethical dilemma|moral dilemmas]], [[metaethics]], [[practical reason]], and [[rationality]] |notable_ideas = |institutions = [[University of Maryland, College Park]], [[University of Chicago]], [[Harvard University]] |influences = |influenced = |signature = }}
'''Patricia Greenspan''' is a professor of philosophy at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]].<ref>[http://philosophy.umd.edu/people/greenspan Patricia S. Greenspan | Department of Philosophy<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Greenspan works in analytic philosophy of action, and is known for work on rationality, morality, and emotion that helped to create a place for emotion in philosophy of action and ethics.<ref>C. Armon-Jones, “Required Feelings,” Times Literary Supplement (1989), 1425; Interview, in J. H. Aguilar and A. A. Buckareff (eds.), Philosophy of Action: 5 Questions (Automatic Press/VIP: 2009); cf. http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/emotion/#toc, http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/envy/, ; http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-dilemmas. http://www.iep.utm.edu/metaethi/, http://www.iep.utm.edu/art-emot/.</ref>
She is the author of two books, ''Emotions and Reasons''<ref>G. Taylor, “Review of Emotions and Reasons: An Inquiry into Emotional Justification, by Patricia S. Greenspan,” 'Philosophy and Phenomenological Research, 50 (1991), 716-719; M. K. Morris, ”Review of Emotions and Reasons by Patricia S. Greenspan,” Noûs, 26 (1992), 250-252; B. N. G., “Review of Emotions and Reasons: an Inquiry into Emotional Justification by Patricia S. Greenspan, Philosophical Quarterly, 46 (1996), 281-282.</ref> and ''Practical Guilt'',<ref>C. W. Gowans, “Review of Practical Guilt: Moral Dilemmas, Emotions, and Social Norms by P. S. Greenspan,” Philosophy and Phenomenological Research, 58 (1998), 730-732; T. McConnell, “Review of P.S. Greenspan’s Practical Guilt,” Ethics, 106 (1996),854-856; cf. M.T. Walker, ”Geographies of Responsibility,” The Hastings Center Report, 27 (1997), 38-44</ref> and numerous articles and book chapters. Her work is cited both within philosophy<ref>E.g., B. W. Helm, “The Significance of Emotions,” American Philosophical Quarterly, 31 (1994), 319-331, 330, n. 13; J. Robinson, “Startle,” Journal of Philosophy, 92 (1995), 53-74; M. A. Wilson, The Emotion of Regret in an Ethics of Response (Proquest, 2007), p. 5, p. 17, pp. 438=49, p. 131; J. Deonna and F. Teroni The Emotions: A Philosophical Introduction (Routledge, 2012), p. 27, p. 55, p. 62, p. 135.</ref> (especially aesthetics<ref>E.g., J. Robinson, Deeper than Reason: Emotion and its Role in Literature, Music, and Art (Oxford University Press, 2005), pp. 22-30, pp. 147-48; R. J. Yanal, Paradoxes of Emotion and Fiction (Penn State Press, 1999), pp. 76-77; A. Pettersson, Verbal Art: A Philosophy of Literature and Literary Experience (McGill-Queen's Press, 2001), pp. 33-34, p. 198.</ref>) and in a number of areas, including medicine,<ref>E.g., M. F. Carr, Passionate Deliberation: Emotion, Temperance, and the Care Ethic in Clinical Moral Deliberation (Springer, 2001) pp. 76-77, p. 94; J. Halpern, From Detached Concern to Empathy : Humanizing Medical Practice (Oxford University Press, 2001), p. 33, p. 46.</ref> law,<ref>E.g., T. E. Pettys, “The Emotional Juror,” Fordham Law Review, 76 (2007), 1609-1640, 1613-14; P. H. Huang, “International Environmental Law and Emotional Rational Choice,” Journal of Legal Studies, 31 (2002), S237-58, S245, n.5</ref> theology,<ref>W. C. Spohn, S.J., ”Notes on Moral Theology: Passions and Principles,” Theological Studies, 52 (1991), 69-87, 76-77.</ref> and education<ref>M. Boler, Feeling Power: Emotions and Education (New York: Routledge, 1999), p. 27.</ref> along with non-scholarly venues.<ref>Total citation count 1017 on https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=QK3L6YYAAAAJ&hl=en, retrieved 4/12/14.</ref> She has given presentations in the U.S. and abroad to interdisciplinary conferences and philosophy department colloquia.<ref name=cv/><ref name=cv>{{cite web|last=Greenspan|first=Patricia|title=Curriculum Vitae|url=http://faculty.philosophy.umd.edu/PGreenspan/Res/cv.html|accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref>
==Education and career== Greenspan graduated from [[Barnard College]], [[Barnard College#Relationship with Columbia University|Columbia University]] summa cum laude with a B.A. in philosophy in 1966.<ref name=cv>{{cite web|title=Curriculum Vitae|url=http://faculty.philosophy.umd.edu/PGreenspan/Res/cv.html}}</ref> In 1972 she received her Ph.D. from the [[Harvard University]] Philosophy Department, receiving the Emily and Charles Carrier Award for the best dissertation in moral philosophy.<ref name=cv /> She then moved to an Assistant Professor position at the [[University of Chicago]], where in 1979 she was awarded tenure and promoted to Associate Professor in the Department of Philosophy and the College.<ref name=cv /> In 1980 she accepted an offer from the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], where she was promoted to full Professor in 1989.<ref name=cv /> Greenspan served as an [[Andrew Mellon]] Fellow at the [[University of Pittsburgh]] for the 1975-76 year,<ref name=cv /> and has received several research fellowships, including from the National Endowment for the Humanities (1983–84),<ref>[https://securegrants.neh.gov/publicquery/main.aspx?q=1&a=0&n=1&ln=Greenspan&fn=Patricia&o=0&k=0&f=0&s=0&p=0&d=0&y=0&prd=0&cov=0&prz=0&wp=0&pg=0&ob=year&or=DESC. NEH Grants<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> the National Humanities Center (1990–91),<ref>{{cite web|title=Fellowships|url=http://nationalhumanitiescenter.org/fellowships/ffellows1.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722182304/http://nationalhumanitiescenter.org/fellowships/ffellows1.htm|archivedate=2011-07-22|df=}}</ref> and the Research School of Social Science at the Australian National University (1995).<ref name=cv />
==Research areas== Greenspan’s principal research interests lie in [[moral philosophy]], [[moral psychology]], and the [[philosophy of action]].<ref name=obio>{{cite web|title=Patricia S. Greenspan {{!}} Department of Philosophy|url=http://philosophy.umd.edu/people/greenspan|publisher=University of Maryland|accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref> Her work has ranged among several interconnected subtopics, as follows:
*[[Deontic logic]]: Greenspan’s Ph.D. dissertation and her first published article dealt with the logic of ought-judgments, arguing that “oughts” are “time-bound” and that wide-scope conditional ought-judgments allow for detachment only when their antecedents are no longer avoidable.<ref>Derived Obligation: Some Paradoxes Escaped (unpublished Ph.D. Dissertation, Harvard, 1972); “Conditional Oughts and Hypothetical Imperatives,” Journal of Philosophy, 72 (1975), 259-76.</ref> *[[Free will]] and [[moral responsibility]]: Greenspan’s second major article and ongoing work argues that freedom depends on the difficulty of doing otherwise, rather than simply ability, and hence admits of degrees.<ref>“Behavior Control and Freedom of Action,” Philosophical Review, 87 (1978), 225-40.</ref> Greenspan’s developed view also distinguishes between freedom and responsibility, arguing that the compatibility of responsibility with free will does not imply a similar compatibilist view of freedom.<ref>“Free Will and Rational Coherency,” Philosophical Issues, 22 (2012), 185-200.</ref> Greenspan has applied some of her work on these subjects to questions arising from the U.S. Genome Project and to the issue of the responsibility of psychopaths.<ref>"Free Will and the Genome Project," Philosophy and Public Affairs, 22 (1993), 31-4; "Responsible Psychopaths," Philosophical Psychology, 16 (2003), 417-29.</ref> *[[Emotion]]: Greenspan next began a long-running project on the rational and moral role of emotion with the publication of an article defending the rationality of ambivalent emotions in an argument designed to cast doubt on attempts by several contemporary philosophers to equate emotions with evaluative judgments or beliefs.<ref>“A Case of Mixed Feelings: Ambivalence and the Logic of Emotion,” in A. O. Rorty (ed.), Explaining Emotions (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1980), pp. 191-204</ref> Her first book argues instead that emotions amount to feelings with an evaluative intentional content short of belief that makes them both susceptible to a distinctive kind of rational assessment and important in a distinctive way to rational and moral motivation, paradoxically serving as a counterforce to weakness of will.<ref>Emotions and Reasons: An Inquiry into Emotional Justification (New York: Routledge, Chapman and Hall, 1988). [0-413-90049-2]. Cf. M. K. Morris, ”Review of Emotions and Reasons by Patricia S. Greenspan,” Noûs, 26 (1992), 250-252; B. N. G., “Review of Emotions and Reasons: an Inquiry into Emotional Justification by Patricia S. Greenspan, Philosophical Quarterly, 46 (1996), 281-282.</ref> A second book and some later essays simplify this account, defend it against some common objections, and apply it to further issues, as outlined below. *[[ethical dilemma|Moral dilemmas]]: In an essay and in her second book Greenspan argues for the coherency of irresolvable moral dilemmas, cases in which all alternatives are forbidden.<ref>Practical Guilt: Moral Dilemmas, Emotions, and Social Norms (New York: Oxford University Press, 1995); cf. “Moral Dilemmas and Guilt,” Philosophical Studies, 43 (1983), 117–125. Also, http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-dilemmas; T. McConnell, “Review of P.S. Greenspan’s Practical Guilt,” Ethics, 106 (1996), 854-856.</ref> She sees dilemmas as a result of the need to establish the motivational force of morality by forging a connection in childhood between emotions and rules simple enough to be learned at that early stage.<ref>Cf. “Learning Emotions and Ethics,” in P. Goldie (ed.), Oxford Handbook of Philosophy of Emotion, pp. 539-59 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2010).</ref> *[[Metaethics]]: Greenspan defends what she calls a “social artifact” version of moral realism, in which morality is invented, yet “real” (in the sense of mind-independent) insofar as it reflects the requisites of life in a viable social group.<ref>Practical Guilt; cf. "Moral Responses and Moral Theory: Socially-Based Externalist Ethics," Journal of Ethics, 2 (1998), 103-22.</ref> She sees emotion as essential to the motivational force of moral judgments in general terms, though not necessarily on each occasion of use or for every agent. She thus departs from contemporary “internalist” understandings of moral meaning that deny the possibility of understanding a moral judgment without being motivated by it. *[[Practical reason]]s and [[rationality]]: Greenspan argues that emotions play a significant role in rational thought, as noted.<ref>For simpler reworking of her original argument cf. “Emotional Strategies and Rationality,” Ethics, 110 (2000), 469-87; “Emotions, Rationality, and Mind/Body,” Philosophy, 52 (2003), 113-25; "Practical Reasoning and Emotion," in A. Mele and P. Rawling (eds.), Oxford Handbook of Rationality (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2004); “Craving the Right: Emotions and Moral Reasons,” in C. Bagnoli (ed.), Morality and the Emotions (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2012).</ref> In recent work she gives an independent account of practical reasons as registering or responding to criticism.<ref>"Practical Reasons and Moral 'Ought'," in Russ Schafer-Landau (ed.), Oxford Studies in Metaethics, Vol. II (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2007), pp. 172-94; cf. "Asymmetrical Reasons," in M. E. Reicher and J. C. Marek (eds.), Experience and Analysis: Proceedings of the 27th International Wittgenstein Symposium (Vienna: oebv&hpt, 2005), pp. 387-94.</ref> The account allows for the rational permissibility in certain cases of action against one’s strongest reason and is brought to bear on issues including the rationality of "satisficing" (choosing less than the best) and the notion of “imperfect” obligation (an obligation that leaves room for options).<ref>“Resting Content: Sensible Satisficing?,” American Philosophical Quarterly, Special Issue on Rationality, 46 (2009), 305-17; "Making Room for Options: Moral Reasons, Imperfect Duties, and Choice," Social Philosophy and Policy, 27 (2010), 181-205.</ref>
==Selected works== *''Conditional Oughts and Hypothetical Imperatives,'' [[Journal of Philosophy]], 72 (1975), 259-76. *''Behavior Control and Freedom of Action,'' [[Philosophical Review]], 87 (1978), 225-40. *''A Case of Mixed Feelings: Ambivalence and the Logic of Emotion,'' in [[Amélie Rorty|A. O. Rorty]] (ed.), ''Explaining Emotions'' (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1980) *''Emotions and Reasons: An Inquiry into Emotional Justification'' (New York: Routledge, Chapman and Hall, 1988). [0-413-90049-2] *''Practical Guilt: Moral Dilemmas, Emotions, and Social Norms'' (New York: Oxford University Press, 1995). [0-19-508762-3] *''Emotional Strategies and Rationality,'' [[Ethics (journal)|Ethics]], 110 (2000), 469-87. *''Practical Reasons and Moral 'Ought','' in [[Russ Schafer-Landau]] (ed.), Oxford Studies in Metaethics, Vol. II (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2007), pp. 172–94. *''Learning Emotions and Ethics,'' in P. Goldie (ed.), The Oxford Handbook of Philosophy of Emotion (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2010). [978-0199654376]

{{Infobox scientist | name = Peter Aczel | birth_name = Peter Henry George Aczel | image = Aczel Rathjen.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Peter Aczel (left) with Michael Rathjen, Oberwolfach 2004 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1941|10|31|df=yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = | workplaces = {{Plainlist| * [[University of Oxford]] * [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] * [[Rutgers University]] * [[University of Manchester]] * [[University of Oslo]] * [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]] * [[Utrecht University]] * [[Stanford University]] * [[Institute for Advanced Study]] * [[Indiana University Bloomington]]}} | alma_mater = [[University of Oxford]] | thesis_title = Mathematical problems in logic | thesis_url = http://www.theses.com | thesis_year = 1967 | doctoral_advisor = [[John Crossley (mathematician)|John Newsome Crossley]] | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Aczel's anti-foundation axiom]] | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|www.cs.man.ac.uk/~petera/}} | footnotes = | spouse = }} '''Peter Henry George Aczel''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|æ|k|s|əl}}; born October 31, 1941) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] mathematician, logician and [[Emeritus]] joint [[Professor]] in the [[School of Computer Science, University of Manchester|School of Computer Science]] and the [[School of Mathematics, University of Manchester|School of Mathematics]] at the [[University of Manchester]].<ref name="mathgene">{{MathGenealogy|59287}}</ref> He is known for his work in [[non-well-founded set theory]],<ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nonwellfounded-set-theory/index.html plato.stanford.edu]</ref> [[constructive set theory]],<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Aczel | first1 = P. | authorlink = Peter Aczel| chapter = An Introduction to Inductive Definitions | doi = 10.1016/S0049-237X(08)71120-0 | title = Handbook of Mathematical Logic | series = Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics | volume = 90 | pages = 739–201 | year = 1977 | isbn = 9780444863881 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Aczel | first1 = P. | authorlink = Peter Aczel| last2 = Mendler | first2 = N. | chapter = A final coalgebra theorem | doi = 10.1007/BFb0018361 | title = Category Theory and Computer Science | series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science | volume = 389 | pages = 357 | year = 1989 | isbn = 3-540-51662-X | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> and [[Gottlob Frege|Frege]] structures.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Aczel | first1 = P.| authorlink = Peter Aczel | chapter = Frege Structures and the Notions of Proposition, Truth and Set | doi = 10.1016/S0049-237X(08)71252-7 | title = The Kleene Symposium | series = Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics | volume = 101 | pages = 31–32 | year = 1980 | isbn = 9780444853455 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref><ref name="dblp">{{DBLP|name=Peter Aczel}}</ref>
==Education== Aczel completed his [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Mathematics]] in 1963<ref name="peter.aczel">[http://www.manchester.ac.uk/research/Peter.Aczel/ Peter Aczel page the University of Manchester]</ref> followed by a [[Doctor of Philosophy|DPhil]] at the [[University of Oxford]] in 1966 under the supervision of [[John Crossley (mathematician)|John Crossley]].<ref name="mathgene"/><ref name="aczelphd">{{cite thesis|degree=DPhil|first=Peter|last=Aczel|authorlink=Peter Aczel|title=Mathematical problems in logic|publisher=University of Oxford|date=1966|url=http://www.theses.com}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
==Career and research== After two years of visiting positions at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] and [[Rutgers University]] Aczel took a position at the [[University of Manchester]]. He has also held visiting positions at the [[University of Oslo]], [[California Institute of Technology]], [[Utrecht University]], [[Stanford University]] and [[Indiana University Bloomington]].<ref name="peter.aczel"/> He was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Study in 2012.<ref>[http://www.ias.edu/people/cos/ Institute for Advanced Study: A Community of Scholars]</ref>
Aczel is on the [[editorial board]] of the Notre Dame Journal of Formal Logic<ref>[http://ndjfl.nd.edu/ Notre Dame Journal of Formal Logic]</ref> and the Cambridge Tracts in Theoretical Computer Science, having previously served on the editorial boards of the [[Journal of Symbolic Logic]] and the Annals of Pure and Applied Logic.<ref name="peter.aczel"/><ref>[http://www.journals.elsevier.com/annals-of-pure-and-applied-logic/ Annals of Pure and Applied Logic]</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

'''Peter Crockaert''' (c. 1465–1514), known as '''Peter of Brussels''', was a Flemish scholastic philosopher.<ref>''...a scholastic of some genius'', [http://www2.nd.edu/Departments//Maritain/etext/homp456.htm].</ref> Initially he was a pupil of [[John Major (philosopher)|John Mair]] and a follower of [[William of Ockham]]. Later he joined the [[Dominican Order]], and became a supporter of orthodox [[Thomism]].<ref>[http://www2.nd.edu/Departments//Maritain/etext/homp452.htm], from the 1909 history by [[Maurice De Wulf]].</ref><ref>''...at first an ardent disciple of the Scot, John Mair, and like him a nominalist, he became a Dominican in 1503 and displayed the greatest zeal for St. Thomas Aquinas.''[http://www.constitution.org/victoria/victoria_2.htm]</ref> He taught at the [[University of Paris]],<ref>''In the first decade of the century Peter Crockaert (died 1514), a Belgian working in Paris, had substituted the [[Summa Theologica|Summa Theologiae]] for what had previously been the standard text for theological instruction, viz. the '[[Sentences]]' of [[Peter Lombard]].'' [[John Joseph Haldane|John Haldane]], ''[http://www.assumption.edu/users/gcolvert/jjhbf1998.htm 1998 Aquinas Lecture]''.</ref> and is known for a number of commentaries, on [[Aristotle]] and [[Peter of Spain (author)|Peter of Spain]] as well as on [[Thomas Aquinas|Aquinas]].
==Notes== <references/>

'''Pride Cymru''' (previously '''Cardiff Mardi Gras''') is a [[Pride]] festival held annually in [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]].
The first Cardiff Mardi Gras took place in [[Bute Park]], Cardiff, in September 1999. The event was an immediate success with over 5,000 attending.{{fact|date=October 2017}} By 2001, the number of attendees had grown to 20,000.<ref name=about>{{cite web| url=http://www.pridecymru.co.uk/about/ | title=About | work=Pride Cymru | location=UK | accessdate=2016-06-07 }}</ref><ref name=2016pics>{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/best-pictures-pride-cymru-festival-11746182|title=The best pictures from the Pride Cymru festival 2016|publisher=[[Wales Online]]|author=Liz Day|date=14 August 2016|access-date=1 August 2017}}</ref>
The 2008 event was cancelled owing to lack of support, but it has been held every year from 2009.{{fact|date=October 2017}} Cardiff Mardi Gras became a registered charity in 2010 and changed its name to Pride Cymru in 2014. Since 2012 the event has included a parade through Cardiff city centre.<ref name=2016pics />
==Controversy: Cardiff Council== In 2016, there was a rumour started that [[Cardiff Council]] had dropped support for the event. <ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-east-wales-37045582 |publisher= [[BBC News]] |date= 13 August 2016 |access-date= 23 October 2017 |title= Pride Cymru: Uncertainty over 2017 LGBT event in Cardiff}}</ref> In an official statement, the Pride Cymru chair said she was told by the council that they'd "made a choice not to allow events during the summer of 2017".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/fears-pride-cymru-find-new-11746674 |date= 18 August 2016|access-date=1 August 2017 |title= Fears Pride Cymru will have to find a new home because of Champions League fanzone|publisher=[[Wales Online]]}}</ref> There was strong local opposition to the decision and the issue prompted a personal appeal from Sir [[Ian McKellen]] in which he compared the negative attitude toward the LGBT community with that seen in India and China on his travels.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-east-wales-37253872|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2 September 2016|access-date=1 August 2017|title=Sir Ian McKellen: Pride 2017 uncertainty 'alarming'}}</ref>
Under intense pressure, Cardiff Council reversed its decision and awarded Pride Cymru a slot later in August to move it away from other major events taking place. The organisers would instead take over the running of the Council's [[Cardiff Big Weekend|Big Weekend]] open-air music festival.<ref name="bigweekend">{{cite web| url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/cardiffs-big-weekend-coming-back-12344130 | title=Cardiff's Big Weekend is coming back – and organisers promise it will be bigger and better | first=Ruth | last=Mosalski | work=WalesOnline | location=UK | date=20 December 2016 | accessdate=20 October 2017 }}</ref>
==Cardiff's Big Weekend== In 2017, Pride Cymru took control of the [[Cardiff Council]]'s 'Big Weekend' and combined it with their LGBT pride parade to form [[Cardiff Big Weekend|Pride Cymrus Big Weekend]].<ref name="bigweekend" /> {{Asof|2017}}, the event is due to continue for at least five years.<ref name="bbc17">{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-east-wales-40964316 | title=Pride Cymru: Under threat event 'safe for five years' | first=Chris | last=Wood | work=[[BBC News]] | publisher=[[BBC]] | location=UK | date=26 August 2017 }}</ref>

{{Infobox scientist |name = Raphael Demos |image = Raphael Demos.jpg |image_size = |caption = Demos in 1927 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1892|1|23}} |birth_place = [[Smyrna]], [[Ottoman Empire]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1968|8|8|1892|1|23}} |death_place = aboard ship, en route to the U.S. |nationality = Turkish, American |fields = [[Moral philosophy]] |workplaces = [[Harvard University]] |education = PhD: [[Harvard University]] |thesis_title = The Definition of Judgment |thesis_url = http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/76981226 |thesis_year = 1916 |doctoral_advisor = [[Alfred North Whitehead]] |doctoral_students = [[Donald Davidson (philosopher)|Donald Davidson]] |notable_students = [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] }} '''Raphael Demos''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|ɛ|m|oʊ|s}}; January 23, 1892 – August 8, 1968) was Alford Professor of Natural Religion, Moral Philosophy and Civil Polity, emeritus, at [[Harvard University]] and an authority on the work of the Greek philosopher [[Plato]]. At Harvard, he taught [[Martin Luther King Jr.]]
== Early life == Demos was born to Ottoman Greek parents at [[Smyrna]] (now Izmir), in the [[Ottoman Empire]], on January 23, 1892.<ref>[http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095709912 Raphael Demos.] Oxford Reference. Retrieved 14 November 2016.</ref><ref name="Shook">{{cite book|author=Shook, John R. (Ed.)|title=The Bloomsbury encyclopedia of philosophers in America: From 1600 to the present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XjM0CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA249|year=2016|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|location=London|isbn=978-1-4725-7056-7|page=249}}</ref> His father had been converted to evangelical Christianity by missionaries and had become an evangelical minister.<ref name="Feinb">{{cite book|author=Feinberg, Barry, & Ronald Kasrils.|title=Bertrand Russell's America: His transatlantic travels and writings. Volume One 1896–1945|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mD3v67J3RxwC&pg=PA40|year=2013|publisher=Routledge|location=Abingdon|isbn=978-1-135-09955-8|page=40}}</ref> Demos was brought up in [[Constantinople]], and earned his A.B. degree in 1910 from [[Anatolia College]] in Marsovan.<ref name="Shook" />
According to the recollections of [[Bertrand Russell]], Demos saved up and traveled [[steerage]] to the United States specifically to improve his education, having read all the books available to him at home.<ref name="Shook" /> Arriving in Boston in 1913 without money, he first worked as a waiter in a restaurant<ref name="Shook" /> and then as a janitor in the Harvard student halls of residence in order to fund his tuition at the university.<ref name="Monk" /> He studied under Bertrand Russell, who was temporarily at Harvard, and Russell found Demos to be one of his best students and was impressed by his enthusiasm for philosophy which he found refreshing.<ref name="Feinb" /><ref name="Monk">{{cite book|author=Monk, Ray|title=Bertrand Russell: The spirit of solitude 1872–1921|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AzssomBIDRIC&pg=PA350|year=1996|publisher=The Free Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0-684-82802-2|page=350}}</ref> Demos obtained his PhD in 1916 for a dissertation titled ''The Definition of Judgment''.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/76981226 ''The definition of judgment''] WorldCat. Retrieved 28 October 2016.</ref> He was naturalized as an American citizen in 1921.<ref name="Shook" /><ref>[https://www.fold3.com/document/14640002/ Raphael Demos › Petition for Naturalization.] fold3. Retrieved 28 October 2016.</ref>
== Family == Demos married Jean and they had a son, [[John Demos]], who attended Harvard University and was a Guggenheim Fellow in United States history in 1977,<ref name=gf /> and a daughter, Penny, who attended [[Radcliffe College]]. Jean was on the staff of the [[New England Conservatory of Music]] from where she later received an honorary doctor of music degree.<ref>[http://necmusic.edu/honorary-doctor-music NEC Honorary Doctor of Music Degree.] New England Conservatory of Music. Retrieved 28 October 2016.</ref> Demos's sister, Dorothy Demetracopoulou, graduated from [[Vassar College]] in 1927.<ref name=vass>[http://newspaperarchives.vassar.edu/cgi-bin/vassar?a=d&d=miscellany19340411-01.2.27 RAPHAEL DEMOS TO LECTURE ON PLATO'S SOCIAL PROGRAM.] ''[[Vassar Miscellany News|The Vassar Miscellany News]]'', Volume XVIII, No. 39, 11 April 1934, p. 4.</ref>
== Career == Demos began his academic career at Harvard as an assistant in philosophy in 1916–17, rising to assistant professor in 1926. He studied at the University of Cambridge in 1918–19.<ref name="Shook" /> He was a [[Guggenheim Fellow]] in 1927, awarded for "a study of the philosophy of evolution and social philosophy, principally in Paris, France",<ref name=gf>[http://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/raphael-demos/ Raphael Demos.] John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation. Retrieved 28 October 2016.</ref> for which he studied at the [[University of Paris]] in 1928–29.<ref name="Shook" /> In 1934, Demos lectured on Plato's social program, arguing that Fascism and Communism had their roots in his philosophy.<ref name=vass /> He became Alford Professor of Natural Religion, Moral Philosophy and Civil Polity in 1945 in succession to [[William E. Hocking]] and he was a member of the Doty committee which produced the report ''[[General education in a free society]]'' completed the same year. He was a fellow of [[Adams House (Harvard College)|Adams House]].<ref name=crim>[http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1968/8/13/professor-raphael-demos-77-dies-praphael/ Professor Raphael Demos, 77, Dies.] ''The Harvard Crimson'', 13 August 1968. Retrieved 28 October 2016.</ref> In 1956, he received an award from the [[Rockefeller Foundation]], as well as from the [[American Philosophy Association]] in 1959 and the [[Littauer Foundation]] in 1960.<ref name="Shook" />
Demos retired from Harvard in 1962 after which he taught at [[Vanderbilt University]] in 1962–63 and 1964–67. He taught at [[McGill University]] in Montreal in 1963–64.<ref name=crim />
In May 1963, Demos wrote to [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] asking whether King had ever been a student of his at Harvard. King replied to say that he had attended the university for two years as a special student and taken Demos's course on the Philosophy of Plato for which he had received an A from Demos. Coincidentally, King's wife, [[Coretta Scott King|Coretta]], had studied with Demos's wife Jean at the New England Conservatory of Music.<ref>[http://www.thekingcenter.org/archive/document/letter-mlk-dr-raphael-demos# Letter from MLK to Dr. Raphael Demos 19 July 1963.] The King Centre. Retrieved 28 October 2016.</ref><ref>John J. Ansbro, ''Martin Luther King, Jr: Nonviolent Strategies and Tactics for Social Change'', Rowman & Littlefield, 1982 , p. 16.</ref>
== Death and legacy == Demos died of a heart attack on 8 August 1968 while on board the [[S.S. Anna Maria|S.S. ''Anna Maria'']] returning to the United States. He had been living in Athens with his wife since 1967, teaching on a university year in Athens course.<ref name=crim /> His papers relating to [[Aristotle]] are held in the archives of Harvard University.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/76973018 Papers of Raphael Demos, ca. 1950-ca. 1969 (inclusive).] WorldCat. Retrieved 28 October 2016.</ref> A volume of essays in Demos's honour was issued in 2016.
== Selected publications == *''The Dialogues of Plato''. Random House, New York, 1920. (Introduction) (Translated by [[Benjamin Jowett]]) *''Plato selections''. C. Scribner's Sons, New York, 1927. (Editor) ([[The Modern Student's Library]]) *''Complete works of Plato''. 1936. (Editor) *''[https://archive.org/details/philosophyofplat001587mbp The philosophy of Plato.]'' Charles Scribner's Sons, New York, 1939. (free download) *"Business and the good society", ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'', July–August 1955. *"The neo-Hellenic enlightenment (1750–1821): A general survey", ''[[Journal of the History of Ideas]]'', Vol. XIX, No. 4 (October 1958), pp. 523–541.
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == *Andriopoulos, D.Z. (2016) ''The idea of Agathon: In honour of Raphael Demos, professor at Harvard University''. Athens: Philosophical Inquiry.

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Sanjay's Super Team | image = Sanjay's Super Team poster.jpg | caption = Film poster featuring (on the bottom) Sanjay and with (from left to right) Durga, Vishnu and Hanuman | director = [[Sanjay Patel]] | producer = [[Nicole Paradis Grindle]] | writer = Sanjay Patel | starring = | music = [[Mychael Danna]] | cinematography = | editing = Kevin Rose-Williams | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Walt Disney Pictures]] * [[Pixar Animation Studios]] }} | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2015|6|15|[[Annecy International Animated Film Festival|Annecy International Animated
Film Festival]]|2015|11|25|with ''[[The Good Dinosaur]]''}} | runtime = 7 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''Sanjay's Super Team''''' is a [[Computer animation|computer-animated]] [[short film]] produced by [[Pixar Animation Studios]]. Written and directed by [[Sanjay Patel]], and based on his childhood, it premiered on June 15, 2015 at the [[Annecy International Animated Film Festival]] in France,{{cite news|last1=Hopewell|first1=John|title=Annecy: U.S., Globalization Fire Up Fest, Market|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/annecy-u-s-globalization-fire-up-fest-market-1201519653/|accessdate=June 20, 2015|work=Variety|date=June 15, 2015}} and accompanied the theatrical release of Pixar's ''[[The Good Dinosaur]]'' on November 25, 2015.{{cite news|last1=Keegan|first1=Rebecca|title=Pixar artist Sanjay Patel gets personal with 'Sanjay's Super Team'|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-pixar-short-sanjay-super-team-20150429-story.html|accessdate=June 20, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=April 29, 2015}} Inspired by Patel's own childhood when he felt conflicted by the modern world and the [[Hindu]] traditions of his family, ''Sanjay's Super Team'' follows the daydream of a young Indian boy, bored with his father's religious meditation, who imagines Hindu gods as superheroes. ==Plot== An intertitle card at the start of the short states that it is based on a (mostly) true story. A young boy, Sanjay, is watching his favorite superhero show, ''Super Team'', while his father is trying to meditate at a small [[Hinduism|Hindu]] [[shrine]] in the same room at home. Each is annoyed by the other's activity until Sanjay's father turns off the television, confiscates his son's ''Super Team'' action figure, and makes him participate in prayer. Sanjay retrieves the toy while his father is distracted, but accidentally sets its cape on fire from the shrine's [[Diya (lamp)|oil lamp]]. While putting out the cape, he extinguishes the lamp as well and is transported to a temple with three stone statues. Suddenly, [[Ravana]] appears and begins to steal the statues' weapons, shattering them in the process. Sanjay breaks the light up mechanism in his toy and uses it to light the giant lamp in the middle of the room, bringing the statues to life as the gods [[Vishnu]], [[Durga]], and [[Hanuman]]. The gods begin to fend off Ravana's attacks and ring their [[Ghanta|bells]] to drive him back, but he retaliates. Sanjay recognizes the giant lamp as an upside down bell and breaks his toy on it to ring it aloud, calming Ravana so that he departs the temple. Sanjay receives a new toy from Vishnu as well as his blessing, then finds himself back in the real world, the cape on his action figure unburnt. His father allows him to continue watching ''Super Team'', and Sanjay surprises him with a drawing that shows the gods watching over the cartoon heroes. The story ends with real life pictures of [[Sanjay Patel]] and his father, during his childhood and in the present day. ==Production== [[File:Sanjay Patel.png|thumb|left|Patel premiered the film at the 2015 [[Annecy International Animated Film Festival]]]] The inspiration for the short film came from Patel's own childhood, growing up in [[San Bernardino, California|San Bernardino]] in the 1980s, in a family of Indian immigrants. Like many American children of the era, he played with [[Transformers]], watched ''[[Looney Tunes]]'' cartoons and read ''[[Superman (comic book)|Superman]]'' comics. He also performed daily [[Hindu]] rituals of meditation and prayer with his father. He felt conflicted by his parents' traditions, saying "Our worlds were diametrically apart. I just wanted my name to be Travis, not Sanjay." Growing up, he became more confident with his identity, although he still found it challenging to openly embrace his Indian background at work. As a child, he "felt deeply the absence of anyone who looked like him in films and television." To "bring a young brown boy's story to the pop culture zeitgeist," Patel first pitched the short to Pixar executives during 2012. Pixar's chief creative officer, [[John Lasseter]], was very welcoming to the idea "about celebrating the personal side of the story." The film's setting was inspired by the Lido Motel, an old [[U.S. Route 66|Route 66]] motel which his parents bought and worked at when he was a child. Patel started the film with only [[Vishnu]], which served as a "mirror of my father" and would contrast one deity with three superheroes. Then the development team suggested adding more gods, with Patel choosing [[Durga]] to showcase a goddess as "in [[Vedas|Vedic]] philosophy, there's always a masculine energy and a feminine energy", and [[Hanuman]] for a half animal deity. Ravana drew inspiration from the various [[Rakshasa]]s, and following Buddhist tradition, "the demon isn't vanquished, he isn't destroyed. Once the boy destroys his idol, it makes the monster more human."{{Cite web|url = https://www.theverge.com/2015/12/8/9869646/sanjays-super-team-sanjay-patel-pixar-interview|title = Pixar's Sanjay Patel on his debut short: 'It was so lovely to have John Lasseter champion it'|date = December 8, 2015|accessdate = December 15, 2015|publisher = The Verge|last = Robinson|first = Tasha}} ==Accolades== ''Sanjay's Super Team'' was nominated for an [[Annie Award]],{{cite news|last1=Giardina|first1=Carolyn|title=Annie Awards: The Complete Winners List|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/2016-annie-award-winners-862117/item/best-animated-feature-2016-annie-861194|accessdate=September 3, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=February 6, 2016}} and for the [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film]].{{cite news|last1=Solomon|first1=Charles|title=A Diverse Pixar Crew Grabs an Oscar Nomination|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/14/movies/a-diverse-pixar-crew-grabs-an-oscar-nomination.html|accessdate=September 3, 2016|work=The New York Times|date=February 8, 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.pixar.com/short-films/sanjays-super-team}} * {{IMDb title|4661600}} {{Pixar}} [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:2015 3D films]] [[Category:2015 computer-animated films]] [[Category:2010s American animated films]] [[Category:2010s animated short films]] [[Category:2010s animated superhero films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films about spirituality]] [[Category:Hindu mythological films]] [[Category:Pixar short films]] [[Category:Theatrically released animated superhero films]] [[Category:3D short films]]
